awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a spark plasma sintering system for engineering advanced materials and composites for use in extreme environments
awd_abstract_narration:
With this Major Research Instrumentation award, the University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB) is acquiring a Spark Plasma Sintering (SPS) facility for advanced material synthesis and consolidation of a wide range of ceramic, metallo-ceramic, and composite powders. This facility enables cutting-edge research serving the College of Arts and Sciences as well as the School of Engineering, and it is available to researchers throughout the state of Alabama. The materials developed via SPS contribute to key technologies in the aerospace, defense, power generation, and industrial processing industries having significant national, economic, and environmental impact. A major objective is to develop novel materials primarily intended for use in extreme conditions of temperature, pressure, electric/magnetic fields, or harsh chemical environments. In addition to supporting several established research programs, the award aims to stimulate new research team projects for junior faculty and to foster collaboration across the state and beyond. The SPS facility is available to student and faculty researchers across the university and to other academic and industrial researchers across Alabama, where there is no instrument with its capabilities. It serves as a focal point of undergraduate/graduate teaching/training within the UAB materials engineering and physics departments leading to enhanced course development in advanced materials fabrication. In addition, the SPS facility is planned for ongoing integration into NSF-funded Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) projects. Community outreach efforts involve partnership with the local science center located in the heart of downtown Birmingham and focus on developing materials exhibits for a broader viewing audience including the general public and K-12 students.

The spark plasma sintering facility features fast and efficient material consolidation (heating or cooling rates up to 1000 °C/min) to aid in the control or prevention of grain growth and ion diffusion. The speed of the process ensures it has the potential of densifying powders with nanosize or nanostructure while avoiding coarsening which accompanies standard densification routes. The facility satisfies the requirements for fabrication of advanced ceramics, namely combined elevated temperature (up to 3000 °C), pressure (up to 259 kN), and controlled environment (inert gas or vacuum) capability. It also features two pressing ranges in one hydraulic cylinder: a low range from 3 – 28 kN for sintering small samples and a high range from 22 – 259 kN for large geometries. The facility enables transformative research at UAB in ultrahigh temperature ceramics, superhard materials, high-pressure physics, plasma physics, laser physics, impurities/defects, nonlinear optics, material degradation in corrosive environments, and development of novel composites. These studies are led by an interdisciplinary team of faculty and will result in fundamental understanding in topics related to densification processes in high entropy ceramics and in metal-ceramic composites, oxidation behavior in high-temperature environments, power generation in middle infrared lasers, ultrafast nanophotonics, novel ternary superconducting thin films, and the role of low-temperature plasmas in materials synthesis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-MRI award to acquire a Spark Plasma Sintering (SPS) system enabled transformative research in ultra-high temperature ceramics, superhard materials, high pressure physics, plasma physics, laser physics, impurities/defects, nonlinear optics, material degradation in corrosive environments, and development of novel composites. It led to fundamental understanding in topics related to SPS densification processes in high entropy ceramics and in metal-ceramic composites, oxidation behavior in high temperature environments, power generation in middle infra-red lasers, ultra-fast nanophotonics, novel ternary superconducting thin films, and the role of low temperature plasmas in materials synthesis. A major objective was to develop novel materials primarily intended for use in extreme conditions of temperature, pressure, electric/magnetic fields, or harsh chemical environments.


A few of the impacts made by the PI’s include:

  • PI Catledge has developed a technique by which high entropy ceramics, first processed using low temperature plasma means, can be further sintered by the spark plasma method to near theoretical density at lower temperatures than is usually reported for these materials. This is likely to make an impact in the field of high entropy ceramics since these materials traditionally suffer from grain growth during high temperature sintering processes, with commensurate reduction in mechanical properties. We aim to show that our approach using this new instrument will result in finer grain size and enhanced mechanical properties.
  • PI Mahapatra densified polymer-derived silicon oxycarbide (SiOC) (~95% relative density) using the SPS unit, indicating that compositionally complex polymer-derived ceramics and composites can be densified. Densification of SiOC is very difficult by conventional sintering methods.
  • PI Mirov developed ceramic gain media for mid-IR lasers with optimal transparency using SPS. This potentially address the limitations associated with traditional fabrication techniques, paving the way for the development of larger, more uniform transition metal-doped ZnSe crystals.
  • PI Ning sintered aluminum and SiC particle reinforced aluminum matrix composites using SPS which led to optimal processing parameters for achieving enhanced hardness via addition of micro-sized SiC particulates.

Other investigators using the SPS have achieved objectives such as: (1) preparing dense covalent ceramics, such as SiC and SiBC, at relatively low temperatures and within a significantly shorter time than by conventional means, and (2) investigating equations of state for high entropy borides under extreme temperatures and pressures.


To date, research utilizing this NSF-MRI facility has led to four peer-reviewed papers published, six conference presentations, and two PhD-dissertations.
Broader impacts from this award led an outreach event organized and hosted by PI Catledge for local 8th-grade students (in partnership with the UAB CORD (Center for Community OutReach and Development) on July 18th, 2023 with focus on the wonders of plasma science/technology. Students visited the PIs lab and experienced “hands-on” activities. Junior faculty PI Dr. Mahapatra has been awarded a UAB Faculty Fellow grant by the School of Engineering to explore the phase transformation of silicon oxycarbide as a function of sintering parameters in SPS and to establish active interdisciplinary collaborative research. This research relied heavily on SPS and led to a proposal submitted to NSF, including another MRI award. The SPS was incorporated into our NSF-REU program:” REU-Site: Regional Initiative to Promote Undergraduate Participation in Experimental and Computational Materials Research” (PI: Y.K. Vohra and S.A. Catledge). This has provided training for several REU students, investigating novel ceramic materials. In addition, approximately five graduate students are now trained as "high-level" users and can impart their experience/training to others.


Education/training in the basic principle of SPS were incorporated in the MSE 470/570 course 'Ceramic Materials' in Spring 2024. Students used SPS to prepare their samples as a part of the laboratory course, comparing the densities of the SPS produced sample with those obtained from conventional sintering methods.


The new SPS instrument extends the current dedicated Materials Processing and Development (MPAD) Laboratory at UAB. MPAD serves the automotive, transportation, defense, infrastructure and energy industries for advanced development of ceramics, plastics and composites design, analysis, processing, manufacture and product development.
